title: Laurel Lake Wildlife Management Area
text:
Laurel Lake Wildlife Management Area is located between <a href="Dingess%2C%20West%20Virginia">Dingess</a> and <a href="Lenore%2C%20West%20Virginia">Lenore</a> in <a href="Mingo%20County%2C%20West%20Virginia">Mingo County</a>, <a href="West%20Virginia">West Virginia</a>. Located on of steep terrain with narrow valleys and ridgetops, the WMA contains second growth mixed <a href="hardwoods">hardwoods</a> and <a href="tsuga">hemlock</a> with thick <a href="understory">understory</a> of <a href="Kalmia%20latifolia">mountain laurel</a> and <a href="rhododendron">rhododendron</a>.
To reach Laurel Lake WMA from Lenore, follow Old Norfolk & Western Railroad Bed Road (County Route 3/5) east about to Laurel Lake.
Hunting and fishing.
Hunting opportunities include <a href="American%20black%20bear">bear</a>, <a href="White%20tailed%20deer">deer</a>, <a href="ruffed%20grouse">grouse</a>, <a href="raccoon">raccoon</a>, <a href="squirrel">squirrel</a>, and <a href="Wild%20turkey">turkey</a>.
Fishing opportunities in the Laurel Lake can include <a href="smallmouth%20bass">smallmouth bass</a>, <a href="channel%20catfish">channel catfish</a>, and <a href="bluegill">bluegill</a>.
Camping is not permitted in the WMA. Camping and lodging are available at nearby <a href="Chief%20Logan%20State%20Park">Chief Logan State Park</a> and <a href="Cabwaylingo%20State%20Forest">Cabwaylingo State Forest</a>.
Dingess Petroglyphs.
The Dingess Petroglyphs serve as one of the more noteworthy attractions at Laurel Lake.
